turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: It could be.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --as far as the Constitution is concerned, because there's nothing to which due process right could attach, a due proces procedural right.
Do we know whether anyone else was exposed to this telephone call, or whatever it was, shall return to the prison within 5 hours?
Was that... how long did the situation persist before the 90-day procedure came into play?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: That was... that regulation came into being 5 months after he was returned to prison in August, I believe.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask if there was a statutory change during that 5-month period?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: There was a statutory change as follows.
There is one... And there was... there's been a couple of misstatements of the record that I would like to clear up here, and I'm not sure of the significance of this--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Before you do, will you tell me what the statutory change was?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --It's one that says... there's an identical provision for both parolees and pre-parolees, and I believe they were enacted at the same time, and that provision says, if you don't keep up with the educational and job requirements that we put on you as a condition, you will become ineligible for parole, and that's the only thing--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And does either the statute before or after that amendment make any reference to the Governor's denial of parole as a reason for terminating pre-parole?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --No, neither before nor after.
One other thing--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But we do have this opinion of the Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals, is it?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Which denied the respondent's writ of habeas at the State level saying, dispositive of the issue in petitioner's case is the fact that he was not granted parole by the Governor.
It is for this, not a disciplinary reason, he was removed from the pre-parole program.

So do we interpret that as meaning that the criminal appeals court thought that not being granted parole was a valid and sufficient reason for revocation of pre-parole status, and that in this very case that was the reason?
I mean, it seems to me what the Oklahoma court is saying.

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: I believe that what they're saying is that it is... they are--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What if we read it that way anyway?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --May I... I just want to make sure that I'm understanding the question.
I do not believe that what they're saying is, you must be brought in, that they did not understand it to mean that.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: That's not the question.

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: They... they understood it--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: The court understood that dispositive of the habeas petition in this very case is the fact that he was not granted, eventually, parole by the Governor, and it was for that reason that his status was revoked, not for some disciplinary reason or some other reason.

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --I believe that I misspoke before--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, what if we interpret that... not you.
What if we, this Court thinks that that constitutes a valid explanation of what the State law was at the time of this revocation?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --Then it seems to me that you should find... you should say that the State law denies due process, and that people must have a hearing, because--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: A hearing to do what, because I think as... first, there's no dispute on the fact that it wasn't any disciplinary reason, right?
You concede--

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --that the only reason given--

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --was that the Governor denied parole, so there'd be no hearing to decide what was the reason.
Everybody agrees that he didn't commit any disciplinary offense.
He was a model--

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --pre-parolee, and he was called back for one reason only, that parole was denied.

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: In parole... a person can admit that they have violated a condition of their release and they're still entitled to a hearing because there's a second decision.
The parole board is exercising discretion.

And Morrissey says, and Gagnon says, and Black v. Romano... it's dictum, but it goes on at considerable length... says, once you're exercising... that's just the first step, did he violate parole, because if they can say he violated but we'll leave him out, then you want to have a chance to argue that you should be one of those people who--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Are you saying that as a result of this pre-release, pre-parole scheme that the discretion the Governor previously had, which I assume was unreviewable, is now in some sense subject to a due process requirement simply because he was on release before the Governor made his discretionary decision?
Is that your argument?

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: --No, not at all, Justice Souter, because there's a huge difference between parole... refusal to grant someone parole and bringing them back into prison.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But all the examples--
--I think the argument you're making is that this excerpt from the Court of Criminal Appeals only establishes that denial of parole is a permissible reason--

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --for revoking pre-parole, not that it is an automatic and mandatory reason.
That isn't established.

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And your point is that if it is only a permissible reason, he should have the opportunity to argue that in this case it shouldn't be permitted.

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Which is the purpose of the 90-day----

--And in support of that you quote from page 11... 41a of the opinion, the last paragraph, where it says the Governor's... where it says, we believe such a procedure gives an inmate sufficient notice when he is placed on the program that he may be removed from it when the Governor exercises his discretion.

turn.speaker: margaret_winter
turn.label: Ms. Margaret Winter
turn.text: Yes, exactly.
I believe that the Criminal Court of Appeals understood it to be discretionary.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Winter.
The case is submitted.
